PRIME MINISTER
TRANSCRIPT OF THE PRIME MINISTER, THE HON P J KEATING MP
DOORSTOP, SYDNEY, RANDWICK RACECOURSE, 6 OCTOBER 1995

E& OE PROOF COPY

PM: I wanted to say some things about John -Howard's Defence-Policy,Â Statement he released yesterday. And if you need to be proofÂ positive that as we squeeze Mr Howard to release policy details, eachÂ one he releases though he has most, of course, secretly cached inÂ his bottom draw but as he releases them, you find that there are noÂ ideas in them, and that they are out of their time. Last week we sawÂ his blunder on Mascot Airport, on the third runway. This week, it's onÂ an even larger topic the question of the nation's defence. And whatÂ his statement reveals, is, I think, what we have been saying of him,Â and that is that he hasn't had a fresh idea since the 1 950s. He saysÂ in this speech that what he calls " unresolved tensions between theÂ Government's focus on the defence partnership with the regionÂ versus the region as a potential source of threats". In other words,Â there's a codeword here which is basically fear of South East Asia,
which underlined all of his call for rebalancing our policy.

So, here we are in the 1990s engaging Asia like as never before, andÂ what's he talking about? He's talking about rebalancing, which
means more fear of our environment, and a bigger gun. He talks
about rebalancing, yet you know, when the leader of Vietnam came
here a few weeks ago 6 weeks or so ago he wouldn't see him. He
wouldn't engage Vietnam, that wants to be a friendly country with
Australia, but he wants us to have a bigger stick and more weapons
against them. At the same time, he won't put any more dollars on the
line to do it. In other words, a complete confusion of objectives and
means. Here he is, basically espousing a 1950s defence policy for
Australia. Closer ties, he calls it, with the United States, fear of the
region he upbraids Gareth Evans for not including the United States
in a map of East Asia, and the main reason for that is, of course, it
isn't in East Asia. And the only map that John Howard wants to see is
the one with the big red arrows coming down again towards Australia,Â so he can run around beating up fear about the strategy environment
the threatening strategic environment we live in.

Australia has completely passed John Howard by. Australia has
passed John Howard by. The changes that have been made here,
the changed environment we now live in an environment of trust and
co-operation with ' ASEAN, in the ASEAN Regional Forum, in the big
bilateral relationships we have with China -and Japan and the United
States, in multi-lateral bodies such as A PEC, in the defence cooperation
we know have around the region, -in'the defence exercises
we have with countries such as Malaysia and Singapore and others,
in these sorts of things, we see from him a complete failure to
understand this. The Indonesians, for instance, in the Kangaroo
exercises this year.

So, what we are seeing is the very thing we always say about John
Howard he's learned nothing since-the-1 950s-If you -want to really.
see a slab of 1950s policy, that was his Defence Statement last night:-
And this is the person who says he should have stewardship of
Australia's Asian relationship someone who fears it, and someone
who wants to put together a bigger defence effort. And, as I made thepoint,
nowhere in his policy were there any extra dollars committed.
He says that our defence relationship with the United States is drifting
Kim Beazley is in Washington at the moment. We have 2 US
warships a guided missile cruiser and a destroyer in Sydney
harbour 1 in Darwin a frigate the 2nd US marine group air
exercise to be held this year Southern Frontier is underway today,
in the Northern territory involving 300 US troops and 18-30 aircraft,
we have also just completed a few weeks ago K~ angaroo 95 our
major exercise with a large US participation of about 2000 US tiRoops,
and black-hawk helicopters, plus 3 US ships. I mean, if we do any
more with them, they will be sitting in our laps it will look like 1945.
But this is the sort of dross and drivel that John Howard's about. You
can understand now why he wants to keep the policies a secret.
Because as he drops them out, you realise he and his party have
come nowhere in 40 years. And whether it was turning our backs on
the gateway to Sydney at Mascot last week, or as it is today dredging
up a 50s defence policy for Australia completely missing the point
about Australia's connections with South East Asia and North Asia,
and our relationship with the United States. Wherever you look, John
Howard's out of his depth, and out of his epoch, and the country has
passed him by. Now, we will see more of this this is why there is
this dichotomy of opinion in the Liberal Party the Andrew Robb's of
this world who want more policies released, and his parliamentary
colleagues who want less because they know they are going to reveal
this sort of tripe. So, I would be glad to take questions from you.

J: John Howard said yesterday when he spoke of the possibility of the
prepositioning of US equipment in Australia. A body that he spoke to,
the Australian Defence Association, suggested that this could involve
for example, 15 merchant vessels in Darwin. Was that the sort of thing
the Government would support?

PM: We have just finished a major exercise, a major mock combat exerciseÂ in Kangaroo 95. As I say you have got this southern frontier 11 hereÂ exercise underway at the moment, this very day. They are the sort ofÂ things you do with the United States and you keep, as well as that,Â apart from strategic engagement in bodies where we have had a hugeÂ influence such as the ASEAN Regional Forum, but you also keep it inÂ the big commercial bodies of engagement between the United States,
Australia and East Asia, in bodies such as APEC. This is what it is allÂ about, we are in a co-operative war, the cold war has finished. JohnÂ Howard is the same person who by the way was telling us that, I mean,Â it was a bit rich I thought, Howard criticising the: Government for not.Â coming to terms with the end of the cold war. I just remind you, he wasÂ still warning Australians of the need to avoid being fooled byÂ Gorbachev and Perestroika in December 1987. He is unbelievable.

J: Do you believe that an increased dialogue with our Asian neighboursÂ is lessening the need for a sharpening of Australia's defence?

PM: No, Australia has developed through our White Paper process of theÂ 1980s a strong defence capability and a forwarfd core defenceÂ capacity, but the complementary policy, the better approach thanÂ simply relying on weapons is to engage the neighbours and to developÂ a friendly co-operation with them. Which, of course, we have. WeÂ have got the best relationships we've ever had in east Asia, south-eastÂ Asia and north Asia. Also, we have got Mr Downer saying ' oh well, weÂ should be concentrating more on north Asia'. Why? We are alreadyÂ doing so much with north Asia, but south east Asia is where we live.

J: What do you say to those critics who say that we are, in fact, too closeÂ to those countries in terms of military relations, that the military areÂ responsible for the ( inaudible on human rights?

PM: What do I say? It is rubbish. I mean, how can you be too close to aÂ nation of 180 million people who are on your doorstop. How can youÂ be too close?

J: Prime Minister, is there a need to have another look at the readyÂ reserve and its relationship with the general reserve, in terms of theirÂ training, morale and those sorts of operations and things?

PM: That question jogs my memory about this Liberal Party magic wandÂ called ' administrative savings'. They are always going to be cuttingÂ money out of the budget. Of course, administrative savings will notÂ fund the sort of spending that they have in mind, but we have from theÂ defence budget, yielded great changes in savings already. In terms ofÂ outsourcing and changing the character of the ADF where a lot of theÂ tasks which are done in-house, within the force, within the ADFÂ structure, will now be done privately and off bases so that more of theÂ ADF will actually be a core combat force and sitting behind that aÂ reserve. That is the direction Australian defence planning and policy isÂ going, but I think, this has just escaped Mr Howard.

J: This morning Mr Howard spoke about another topic, he quoted theÂ ALP President Barry Jones suggesting that the Government is going toÂ increase tax.

PM: Barry Jones has written another book and in that book he talks aboutÂ some of the subjects that he has been quite learned about. About theÂ information age, about how he thinks the nature of work is changing,Â about how national governments will respond to this... This has got no--Â implications for the national policy at all.

J: Do you reject claims from Mr Howard that you are thinking ofÂ increasing taxes?

PM: Mr Howard was the highest taxing Treasurer in Australia's history. MrÂ Howard had taxes to GDP higher than any one in Australian federal
history. He left me the dirty work of bringing taxes down. When he leftÂ office the bottom rate of tax was 30 per cent. It is now 20 per cent.
When he left office the tax free threshold was $ 4,500. It is now $ 5,450Â from memory. When he left office the top marginal rate was 60 perÂ cent. It is now 47 per cent. When he left office the company rate was
46 per cent. It is now 36 per cent.Â 

J: So you reject his claims?

PM: It is just tripe, as most of the things he says about economic policy areÂ and certainly about taxation.

J: Any comment concerning the story this morning out of Washington, inÂ the Financial Review, about IMF warning Australia on interest rates?

PM: I think there is a bit of reading into behind what the I MF said. The IMFÂ does a study on Australia as it does on most other countries, all theÂ OECD countries every year and they give us a running commentary onÂ economic policy, but they don't give a month by month, quarter byÂ quarter account on monetary policy or interest rates and I just thinkÂ whoever wrote the story read too much into it. Thank you.
